review_title: Incredibly rewarding work in a beautiful location
pros:
Working at The Children's Trust is such a rewarding experience because you get to see first-hand the difference it makes to the young people the charity supports. Witnessing these youngsters overcome adversity is hugely inspirational and always a motivation to work hard and develop your own skills.

No two days are alike and the range of people you get to meet and collaborative with keeps things interesting. Opportunities are always there for those who are proactive and willing to stick their neck out.

The work life balance is good, I rarely have to work beyond my usual hours, but always feel willing to do so due to the general can-do and positive attitude of the organisation. The grounds are stunning and probably the biggest perk. Being able to walk around the rose gardens and woodlands on a lunch break really helps with mental well being.

The people are also a positive reason for working here, although collaboration and communication could be better, there's generally a feeling of good will and staff always prepared to help each other out.

The benefits package – named ZEST – is decent and includes a huge range of staff discounts as well as other standard benefits such as discounted on-site childcare.

In general the organisation feels like it's going through a bit of a coming-of-age period  in a bid to be run more like a professional business, hopefully it won't lose the genuine, kind and caring legacy it inherently has as a children's charity along the way.
cons:
As a charity, understandably the benefits package isn't as generous as other industries, but that's to be expected and the People team definitely work hard to make it competitive. 

Investment in technology could be improved, but things are moving in the right direction.

In support roles, I think career progression is fairly limited, but if you're prepared to learn skills outside of your comfort zone, there are definitely opportunities.
